list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I thought I might find you here
He might come if you offered him a meal.

list_definition.mean_english: sử dụng trong lời đề nghị lịch sự
list_definition.definition: used instead of ’may’, eg to make a possibility seem less likely, or a request for permission more polite

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He might win if he tries hard
Might I speak to you for a few minutes, please?

list_definition.definition: used in suggesting that a person is not doing what he should

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: You might help me clean the car!
The might of the opposing army was too great for us.

list_ex_of_english: Problems, then, are raised about the ecological validity of this constraint and the role it might play in the perception of ordinary, everyday motion.
It is this affective and evaluative progress that teachers might try to develop in pupils in order to develop their skills of musical thinking further.
Having only one parent might have meant a household necessity of replacing the loss/absence of one parent.
A critic of the data protection regime might note that the legislation protects debtors with more force than it does creditors.
The reported information on the form thus might not correspond to the reality of facts.
In this situation it was equally possible that other interested parties might want to strengthen the international reputation of the incumbent government.
A number of respondents thought they might be safer than ordinary bulbs, as they needed to be changed less often.
Patients might be ranked differently with different prioritization measures.
